questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of mild pain in his right shoulder following a minor fall. The X-ray is shown below. There is no significant swelling or erythema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the cause of the indicated arrow?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The given X-ray shows an elevated periosteum All of the options mentioned above can show periosteal elevation Differentials of elevated periosteum Vascular Haemophilia and other bleeding disorders Myeloid metaplasia (thrombocytopenia) Erythroblastic anemias Leukaemias Varicose veins Hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy Pachydermoperiostosis Physiologic Prematurity Dysplastic Melorheostosis Engelmann's disease Traumatic Local subperiosteal trauma Fractures (including march fractures) Unrecognized skeletal trauma (Caffey's syndrome) Hypo/Hypervitaminosis Rickets Scurvy Hypervitaminosis A Infective Acute osteomyelitis (staphylococcal, streptococcal, pneumococcal) Brodie's abscess Tuberculosis Syphilis (congenital and acquired) Neoplastic Primary: Benign :meningioma, angioma, osteoid osteoma Malignant: osteogenic sarcoma (only this is called Codman's triangle) , fibrosarcoma, Ewing's

questions.question: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the visit, he shared his family history of bone tumors, mentioning that several relatives have passed away from various types of bone cancers. Concerned about his own risk, he asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy he should be most vigilant about.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Multiple Myeloma Explanation: Multiple myeloma is the most common bone tumor in older adults, particularly those aged above 40 years. It originates from malignant plasma cells in the bone marrow. Given the patient’s age, multiple myeloma is a significant concern. Osteochondroma (Option A): The most common age group is teenagers. Osteoclastoma (Option B): Occurs between 15-35 years of age. Ewing's Sarcoma (Option C): Occurs between 15-25 years of age. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 214, 217, 206 Multiple Myeloma - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with persistent pain and swelling in her right knee that has been worsening over the past few months. During her family history discussion, her mother recalls that a distant relative had primary bone cancer in their youth. Concerned about the possibility of a serious condition, the girl asks the doctor which type of bone malignancy is most commonly seen in adolescents like her.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Osteogenic Sarcoma Explanation: Osteogenic sarcoma (osteosarcoma) is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in adolescents, typically occurring around the knee. Given the girl's age, osteosarcoma is the most relevant malignancy to consider. Osteosarcoma Type Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma) Origin Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin Tissue Origin Solid malignant bone tumor Age Group Bimodal distribution: peaks in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade Gender Prevalence More common in males than females Common Sites 1. Lower end of femur 2. Upper end of tibia Location of Origin Arises from the metaphysis of long bones Synovial sarcoma (Option B): Uncommon malignant tumor. Reticulum cell sarcoma (Option C): Uncommon malignant tumor. Ewing’s sarcoma (Option D): Ewing sarcoma is not the most common malignant bone tumor, but it is the second most common in children and young adults. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559183/#:~:text=Ewing%20sarcoma%20(ES)%20is%20a,bone %20tumor%2C%20predominantly%20afflicting%20adolescents . Textbook of Orthopedics- John Ebnezar, 5th Edition, Pages 604-606

questions.question: All of the following are correctly matched bone tumors except? 1. Most common bone tumors Secondaries 2. Most common primary benign bone tumor Osteoblastoma 3. Most common primary malignant bone tumor Osteogenic sarcoma. 4. Most Common bone tumor in elderly Multiple myeloma.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2 Explanation: The most common benign bone tumor is: Osteochondroma Osteoblastoma is an uncommon benign tumor of bone. 1. Most common bone tumors Secondaries from: Prostrate Breast Kidney Thyroid Lung Pb KTL (Lead Kettle) 2. Most common primary benign bone tumor Osteochondroma 3. Most common primary malignant bone tumor Osteogenic sarcoma. 4. Most Common bone tumor in elderly Multiple myeloma. Osteochondroma Also Called Exostosis Type Most common primary benign bone tumor Structure An offshoot from spongy bone tissue with a cartilaginous cap Cause Due to unwanted activity of the cambium layer of the periosteum Most Common Age Growth period (teenagers, during growth spurts) Gender Preponderance Male Most Common Site Lower end of the femur 2nd Common Site Upper end of the tibia Location Around the knee joint; commonly around the metaphysis of long bones and crest of ilium Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 192-194 Textbook of Orthopedics- John Ebnezar, 5th Edition, Page 613 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536954/#:~:text=Osteo blastoma%20is%20an%20uncommon%20benign,appropriate%20treatment%20modality%20and%20prognosis .

questions.question: A 70-year-old female presents with a two-week history of left thumb pain and swelling. She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and triple-negative carcinoma of mammary origin, diagnosed five years prior. Physical examination reveals swelling and mild ulceration at the distal first phalanx. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most common underlying cause of the patient's thumb lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Secondary carcinoma from another site Explanation: The most common underlying cause of the thumb lesion in this case is secondary carcinoma from Breast carcinoma because: The patient has a history of triple-negative carcinoma of mammary origin (Breast Ca) indicating metastasis to the distal phalanx. The X-ray findings indicate a lytic lesion. Metastatic Tumors to Bone Common Metastatic Tumors Lung

questions.question: A 20-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of progressively worsening thigh pain, initially accompanied by intermittent fevers and malaise. Recently, her pain has intensified to the point of bedridden status. She develops acute confusion and altered consciousness, with laboratory tests revealing severe hypercalcemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ewing's sarcoma Explanation: Ewing's sarcoma is the most likely diagnosis due to: The patient's age (20 year old) The presence of progressively worsening thigh pain (femur), and severe hypercalcemia, which is atypical but has been documented in cases of Ewing's sarcoma. The X-ray findings of

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of worsening back pain, fatigue, and significant weight loss. He also reports frequent headaches, difficulty concentrating, and numbness in his legs. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lumbar spine and decreased sensation in the lower extremities. Laboratory investigations show normocytic anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals the presence of Bence Jones proteins. A skeletal survey is done. Which of the following is NOT a typical radiological feature of the patient’s most likely condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sunburst appearance in long bones Explanation: The clinical presentation and investigation findings are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. All of the options except sunburst appearance are typical radiological features in a case of multiple myeloma. Sunburst appearance in long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma. Multiple myeloma: It is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. It is the malignant proliferation of plasma cells of the B-cell lineage within the bone marrow. Common age group: Around 70 years of age. Men > Female. Pathology: Increased production of plasma paraprotein and immunoglobulin. Tumor tissue replaces the bone and there is no reactive bone formation. Histopathology: Bone marrow is hypercellular and diffusely infiltrated by plasma cells. Clinical manifestations: Severe pain in the lumbar and thoracic spine is the most common symptom. Pathological fractures. Local tenderness over the affected bones. Fatigue, and loss of weight. Neurological symptoms. Medical complications: Anaemia, hypercalcemia, hyperviscosity, immunosuppression, and renal dysfunction . Investigations: Skeletal survey to screen for bone lesions, and assess tumor burden and fracture risk: X-rays of the spine, skull, pelvis, ribs/sternum, and the humerus/femurs. Multiple punched-out lesions in the skull and other flat bones. In the skull, it may cause a ‘pepper-pot’ appearance. (Options A & B ruled out) Pathological wedge collapse of the vertebra (Common in the thoracic spine). (Option C ruled out) A. A lateral X-ray of the lumbar spine shows diffuse osteopenia and a pathologic compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body (arrow). B. A midsagittal T2-weighted MRI taken several months later shows extensive marrow infiltration and compression fractures of many vertebral bodies. CT is superior to X-ray for demonstrating fractures, osteolytic lesions, and soft-tissue masses. Urine: Bence Jones proteins Serum electrophoresis: Abnormal spike in the gamma globulin region (myeloma spike). Bone marrow biopsy : From the iliac crest. CT guided needle biopsy from the vertebral lesion. Treatment: Treatment of choice: Autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT). Bisphosphonates to control hypercalcemia. In transplant-ineligible patients: Bortezomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (VRd). Daratumumab, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (DRd).

questions.question: A 25-year-old male has pain and progressive swelling around the proximal part of the left hand for the last 3 months. The X-ray is shown below. A biopsy reveals small, round cells forming pseudo-rosettes. Which of the following is not correct regarding the diagnosis of this patient?

options.A: It is a highly malignant tumor of bone, commonly involving diaphysis.
options.C: The tumor is highly radio-sensitive but prone to recurrence.
options.D: Males are more likely to be affected than females.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bone-to-bone metastasis is not common. Explanation: The clinical picture and onion peel appearance in the proximal part of the shaft of the left humerus on the X-ray are consistent with a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma. Bone-to-bone metastasis is very common, making metastasis a frequent and challenging complication. Ewing's sarcoma Highly malignant tumor. (Option A ruled out) Cell of origin: Mesenchymal stem cells in the bone marrow. Age group: 10-20 years of age. Males > Females. (Option D ruled

questions.question: A 27-year-old female is diagnosed with a giant cell tumor in her distal femur after presenting with vague pain and swelling. She undergoes surgical excision of the tumor. Which of the following pre-operative X-ray findings is most consistent with giant cell tumors?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Soap bubble appearance Explanation: Soap bubble appearance is the characteristic radiological finding of giant cell tumors. It presents as a lytic lesion with multiple internal septations, giving it a soap bubble appearance. It is usually located in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur. X-ray findings in Giant cell tumors (GCTs): Eccentric location, often subchondral. Expansion of the overlying cortex. The cortex may be thinned out. Lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition produce a soap bubble appearance. (Option C) No calcification within the tumor. No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor. The tumor usually does not enter the adjacent joint. Treatment: The treatment of choice is excision . Followed by reconstruction procedures and bone grafting or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) insertion. Adjuvant treatments: Liquid nitrogen and phenol have been shown to decrease recurrences. Bisphosphonates like zoledronate or pamidronate Radiotherapy- especially for spine GCTs Drugs: Denosumab- anti-RANKL monoclonal antibody. Sun-rays appearance (Option A): It is typically seen in osteosarcoma. As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor which resembles rays of the sun. Onion peel appearance (Option B): It is associated with Ewing's sarcoma. It refers to concentric layers of rapid new periosteal bone formation that resemble the layers of an onion. Pepper pot appearance (Option D): It is commonly seen in multiple myeloma. The pepper pot or punched-out appearance refers to multiple small, round lytic lesions in the skull caused by the tumor.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive and persistent vague pain and swelling around her right knee for the past 3 months. On physical examination, there is swelling around the distal femur with tenderness. Histopathology shows multinucleated giant cells and spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nature of the tumor in this patient?

options.A: It commonly arises from the diaphysis of long bones
options.B: It is benign but can behave aggressively locally
options.C: It most frequently metastasizes to regional lymph nodes
options.D: It most commonly affects individuals under the age of 20

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is benign but can behave aggressively locally Explanation: The clinical manifestation and histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of a giant cell tumor. It is classified as benign but can behave aggressively in the local area, causing extensive bone destruction. Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone. (Option B) It commonly arises from epiphysis. (Option A ruled out) MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age. (Option D ruled out) Females > males. Most Common sites affected: Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum. Malignant transformation in <1% of cases. Lungs are the most common site for metastases. (Option C ruled out) Histopathology: Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells. Clinical features: Swelling, vague pain. Pathological fracture. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page 198 Giant Cell Tumor (Osteoclastoma) - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy presents to orthopedics OPD with mild fever and intermittent thigh pain for the past several months, particularly at night. There is no history of fever and weight loss. On physical exam, there is swelling and tenderness over the distal femur. An X-ray image is shown below. Which of the following best explains the radiological finding in osteosarcoma that is marked with an arrow in the above image?

options.B: It represents tumor calcification within the bone
options.C: It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone
options.D: It indicates early metastasis to the nearby soft tissue

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It is a result of the tumor breaking through the periosteum, lifting it off the bone osteosarcoma , which lifts the periosteum off the bone. X-ray findings of osteosarcoma: Area of irregular

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain around her left ankle for the past 6 months. The pain is worse at night and unresponsive to analgesics. On examination, there is a firm, poorly defined, tender mass over the distal femur, with shiny skin and prominent veins over the swelling. The X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the most common site of origin for the bone tumor that the patient is having in this case?

options.A: Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Metaphysis of long bones Explanation: Based on the demographics of the patient, clinical manifestation, and X-ray showing sunburst appearance, the most probable diagnosis is osteosarcoma. It most commonly originates in the metaphysis of long bones. Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

questions.question: Match column A (cell type) with column B (tumor) according to the Lichtenstein Classification of bone tumors. Column A Column B 1. Bone a. Giant cell tumor 2. Cartilage b. Eosinophilic granuloma 3. Bone marrow c. Exostosis 4. Uncertain d. Osteoid osteoma
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a Explanation: Lichtenstein Classification of Bone Tumors Cell Type Benign Malignant Bone Osteoid osteoma Osteosarcoma Cartilage Chondroma or Enchondroma Osteochondroma or exostosis Chondrosarcoma Fibrous Tissue Fibroma Fibrosarcoma Bone Marrow Eosinophilic granuloma Ewing's sarcoma Multiple myeloma Vascular Haemangioma Angiosarcoma Uncertain Giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma) Malignant giant cell tumor Reference: Essential Orthopaedics Including Clinical Methods- Maheshwari, 6th Edition, Page 236

questions.question: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the epiphysis extending to the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Aneurysmal bone cyst Explanation: An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is often characterized by an expansile, lytic lesion, and its FNA typically yields a bloody aspirate due to the cystic, vascular nature of the lesion . Hemosiderin-laden macrophages are commonly seen due to prior hemorrhage within the cyst. Giant cell tumor (GCT) (Option A) can also present as an expansile lytic lesion, but it usually involves the epiphysis without such a significant cystic, vascular component or bloody aspirate on FNA. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) Age Primarily affects children and teenagers Most common in young adults (15-35 years) Gender Equal distribution between males and females More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1) Location Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia) Symptoms Pain and swelling ; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues Swelling without pain ; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture Histology FNAC: Hemosiderin + Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae FNAC: No hemosiderin Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy Radiology Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction Treatment Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously) Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy Osteosarcoma (Option C): It is a malignant tumor that presents with mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions rather than a purely lytic, expansile lesion with a bloody aspirate. Chondroblastoma (Option D): It is a rare benign tumor that affects the epiphysis, usually seen in younger patients, but it does not typically show a bloody aspirate or hemosiderin deposits on FNA. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 198, 199, 201, 202. Textbook of Orthopedics- John Ebnezar, 5th Edition, Pages 608, 609.

questions.question: A 15-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, painful swelling over the distal femur. On examination, the swelling is tender and firm. X-ray shows an expansile, lytic lesion with multiple fluid levels in the metaphysis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Aneurysmal bone cyst Explanation: Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign, expansile, osteolytic lesion that commonly affecmetaphysis of long bones in adolescents. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) A benign, expansile bone lesion composed of blood-filled cystic spaces. Epidemiology Primarily affects children and teenagers ( 10 to 30 years ). Males > Females Location Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus). Located subperiosteally. Presentation Pain and Swelling. Radiological Features X-ray: Radiolucent area situated at the metaphysis. Osteolytic, poorly defined lesion elevating and eroding the cortex. MRI: Multiple intralesional septations and fluid levels. Angiography : Persistence of contrast and a blush of flow within the lesion. Histology Composed of blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae. In chronic cases, the septae may contain woven bone. Treatment Surgery: Curettage and bone grafting Giant cell tumor (Option A): It usually occurs in adults near the ends of long bones, show a lytic lesion without fluid levels, and often extend into the subchondral bone. Osteosarcoma (Option B): It is a malignant bone tumor that presents with aggressive, mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions like Codman's triangle or sunburst appearance. Osteoid osteoma (Option D): It is a small, benign lesion typically causing nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs, and appears as a small nidus surrounded by sclerosis on imaging .

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of a slowly growing, painless swelling on the forehead for the past 3 years. On examination, a hard, immobile mass is palpated. A CT scan shows a dense, well-circumscribed, bony lesion in the frontal sinus. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ivory osteoma Explanation: The given scenario with a history of a slowly growing, painless swelling on the forehead and a CT scan showing a dense, well-circumscribed, bony lesion in the frontal sinus is suggestive of Ivory osteoma. Ivory Osteoma / Compact Osteoma: It is a painless condition affecting membranous bones or soft tissues. Two Types Homoplastic: arises purely from bone Heteroplastic: arises from soft tissues Most common site: The outer surface of the Skull (especially in front of the frontal sinus ) Presentations: Cosmetic problems Mucocele. It can become a space-occupying lesion (if the inner table of the skull is involved) and can predispose to epilepsy . Treatment: Excision Fibrous dysplasia (Option A) is a benign bone disorder where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, often presenting as ground-glass opacity on imaging rather than a dense, sclerotic lesion. This option is incorrect. Osteosarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor that typically presents with pain, aggressive growth, and mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance on imaging, unlike the slow-growing, dense ivory osteoma. This option is incorrect. A dermoid cyst (Option D) is mobile when palpated and does not appear bony on a CT. This option is incorrect. Reference:

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy presents with persistent pain in his right leg, which is worse at night and relieved by ibuprofen. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no swelling or warmth over the affected area. An X-ray of the right leg is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Osteoid Osteoma Explanation: The patient presenting with persistent pain, relieved by NSAIDs and an X-ray showing a characteristic lesion with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus, points towards an Osteoid Osteoma. Osteoid Osteoma A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone Demographics Sex: Males > Females Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30. Location The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.

questions.question: A 19-year-old male presents with mild, intermittent knee pain for 6 months. X-ray shows an eccentric, lytic lesion in the proximal tibial metaphysis without periosteal reaction. Biopsy reveals stellate cells in a myxoid background. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chondromyxoid Fibroma Explanation: A teenager presenting with mild intermittent pain and an Xray showing an eccentric, lytic lesion in the proximal tibial metaphysis without periosteal reaction with a biopsy showing stellate cells in a myxoid background is suggestive of Chondromyxoid Fibroma. Chondromyxoid Fibroma The least common, benign cartilaginous bone tumor Demographics Sex: Slightly more common in males. Age: Teenagers and young adults ( 2nd and 3rd decade of life). Location Metaphyses of long bones, particularly the proximal tibia and pelvis. Presentation Slow-growing swelling with pain Radiology X-ray: Small, metaphyseal, eccentric lytic lesions, lying parallel to the bone's long axis. The cortex is expanded, thin, and interrupted. Medullary margins are scalloped and sclerosed. It erupts through the cortex with minimal periosteal or soft tissue reaction . Histology Stellate cells on a myxoid background . Mitotic figures are rare, though cellular atypia may occur. Treatment Small tumors: Local excision and bone grafting large tumors: Wide en bloc excision Osteosarcoma (Option A) typically presents with aggressive features, such as a sunburst periosteal reaction and pain worsening at night. Osteoid Osteoma (Option C) usually causes severe, night-time pain, is relieved by NSAIDs, and has a small central nidus on imaging. Giant Cell Tumor (Option D) is more common in the epiphysis, often with expansile and lytic lesions.

questions.question: A 15-year-old male presents with localized pain and joint stiffness around the knee. Radiographic examination reveals a well-defined lytic lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone. Histological analysis shows a "wet-sawdust" appearance and "chicken-wire" calcification. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.A: It is most commonly diagnosed in patients over 35 years of age.
options.B: They are confined within the epiphyses of long bones.
options.C: Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment.
options.D: It is more prevalent in females compared to males.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases after treatment. Explanation: This case points towards a diagnosis of Chondroblastoma. Recurrence of chondroblastoma is observed in about 10% of cases, indicating the need for careful monitoring. Chondroblastoma Type: Benign but potentially aggressive bone tumor Commonly Affected Age Group: Primarily affects children and adolescents (Option A ruled out) Epidemiology Aspect Details Prevalence < 1% of all bone neoplasms Age Distribution Peak incidence at 10-20 years; rare <10 or >35 years Gender More prevalent in males than females (Option D ruled out) Clinical Presentation Main Symptom: Localized pain Additional Symptoms: Joint effusion and stiffness, especially near joints Location Typical Sites: Epiphyses of long bones (especially around the knee) Potential extension across the physis (growth plate) (Option B ruled out) Radiographic Features Feature Description Appearance Well-defined, round or oval lytic lesions Size Typically 1 to 7 cm Cortical Expansion May show expansion without breach MRI Characteristics Homogeneous high-signal lesions Histological Features Microscopic Appearance: Characteristic "wet-sawdust" appearance Key Components: Chondroid matrix Calcification Hemorrhage Pathognomonic Features: "Chicken-wire" calcification ABC-like areas in ~35% of cases Treatment Options Treatment Description Curettage Tumor scraping with/without bone grafting Radiofrequency Ablation Minimally invasive heat treatment En-bloc Resection Aggressive removal with healthy margin for recurrence Joint Preservation Focus on maintaining adjacent joint integrity Recurrence Approximately 10% chance of recurrence (Option C)

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents with a well-defined, radiolucent lesion in the distal phalanx of the hand. Radiographic findings reveal rounded, lobulated edges with characteristic "popcorn-like" opacities. The lesion measures 4 cm in diameter and is asymptomatic. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Serial X-rays for monitoring Explanation: Serial X-rays for monitoring are appropriate for asymptomatic chondromas, as they typically stop growing after skeletal maturity. Chondroma: Summary of X-ray Findings and Treatment X-ray Findings Chondromas present as: Well-defined, radiolucent lesions Surrounded by a thin border of reactive sclerosis Typically located centrally in the bone with: Rounded, lobulated edges Internal characteristics: "Popcorn-like," "glandular," or "ring-like" opacities indicating calcification Rarely exceed 6 cm in diameter Treatment Asymptomatic Chondromas : No treatment required : (Option D ruled out) Symptomatic Chondromas : Treatment options include: Curettage : (Option A ruled out) Scraping out tumor tissue from the bone Recommended for symptomatic lesions in the hand or in cases of pathological fractures Serial X-rays : (Option B- more appropriate) Monitor size changes post-skeletal maturity Growth after maturity may indicate malignant transformation, necessitating further evaluation and treatment Immediate surgical excision (Option C) : Not necessary since the lesion is asymptomatic and likely benign.

questions.question: An X-ray image shows multiple large chondromas in the hands and feet of a 28-year-old female patient. Based on this radiological finding, which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

options.A: The presence of large chondromas may indicate a higher risk of malignant transformation.
options.B: These chondromas can lead to bone expansion and thinning of the cortex.
options.C: Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.
options.D: Patients with multiple chondromas have an increased risk of extra-skeletal malignancies

questions.explanation: malignant transformation. Correct Answer: C) Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation. Explanation: It is a case of Multiple Enchondromatosis associated with Maffucci syndrome. Surgical excision may be indicated for symptomatic chondromas or those showing signs of malignant transformation, it is not necessary to excise all chondromas as a preventive measure. Multiple Enchondromatosis Definition: Condition characterized by numerous benign cartilaginous tumors (chondromas). Associated Conditions: Ollier's disease- only enchondromas Maffucci syndrome- enchondromas + hemangiomas Ollier's Disease Feature Details Clinical Presentation Usually diagnosed in childhood Most chondromas found in phalangeal bones Common findings: Asymmetric limb shortening Swelling of fingers/toes Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints Distribution Can be unilateral or bilateral Progression New chondromas typically stop after puberty Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy Risk of pathological fractures Malignant Transformation 20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s Warning signs: Increase in size of existing chondroma New symptoms Maffucci Syndrome General Features of Multiple Chondromas Feature Details Clinical Presentation Multiple chondromas with hemangiomas Symptoms can appear at birth or later Radiographic Features X-rays show large chondromas Possible bone expansion and cortex thinning (Option B ruled out) Malignant Transformation Risk of secondary chondrosarcoma > 50% (Option A ruled out) Similar timing for malignant transformation as Ollier's disease Increased risk for carcinomas (breast, liver, ovary) (Option D ruled out) Radiographic Appearance Large chondromas visible on X-rays Histological Features Higher cellularity and proliferative potential compared to solitary chondromas Feature Details Malignant

questions.question: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with a chondroma following imaging and histological examination. Which of the following statements regarding chondromas is false?

options.A: Chondromas are generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity.
options.B: Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures.
options.C: Chondromas commonly occur in the tubular bones of the hand.
options.D: Serial X-rays can help monitor for malignant transformation in chondromas.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Most chondromas are symptomatic and present with pain or fractures. pain or fractures. Chondroma: Etiology and Clinical Features Etiology Incidence : Unknown due to the asymptomatic nature of most chondromas, which are often found incidentally. Clinical Features Aspect Details Location Predominantly found in tubular bones of the hand. (Option C ruled out) Other common sites include the femur and humerus. Symptoms Mostly asymptomatic; often discovered via radiography. May cause pain or pathological fractures in some cases. Growth Generally slow-growing, ceasing post-skeletal maturity. (Option A ruled out) Malignant Transformation Typically benign, but differentiation from low-grade chondrosarcoma (grade 1) is challenging. Indicators of chondrosarcoma include: Increased cellularity Enlarged nuclei Presence of multiple double-nucleated cells Infiltration into marrow spaces and haversian system Serial X-rays are useful for monitoring potential malignancy; growth post-skeletal maturity may signal transformation. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 192- 194

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with a bony swelling near his knee. He denies pain or any recent trauma. X-ray shows a pedunculated bony outgrowth growing away from the joint, with a thin outer cortex and cancellous structure. What is the next step in management?

options.D: MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Observation and follow-up Explanation: Asymptomatic osteochondromas typically do not require treatment unless there are signs of complications such as pain, nerve compression, or concern for malignancy. Osteochondroma: X-ray, Treatment, and Complications X-ray Appearance Bony protuberance with distinct edges. Widened host bone cortex extending into the osteochondroma. Features may include: Thin outer cortex, cancellous structure. Pedunculated (cauliflower-like) or sessile base. Pedunculated types grow away from joints, toward the diaphysis. MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness (Option C ruled out) Reserved for cases where malignant transformation is suspected. Biopsy to rule out malignancy (Option D ruled out) Indicated without symptoms such as pain or rapid growth. Treatment Asymptomatic osteochondromas: No treatment required. (Option B) Excision indicated for: (Option A ruled out) Large lesions causing pressure. Concern for malignant transformation in adults. Complications Complication Description Painful bursa formation Due to friction over the osteochondroma. Activity-related discomfort General discomfort with movement. Nerve compression Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms. Fracture Uncommon, results in sudden pain. Malignant transformation Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm. Malignant transformation risk factors: Large cartilage cap (>1.5 cm on MRI). Osteochondroma location: More common in the trunk, rare in extremities. Risk Factors: Increased size or new pain after skeletal maturity, especially in Multiple Osteochondromas. Reference:

questions.question: A 14-year-old male presents with a painless, hard mass near his proximal humerus. Imaging reveals a bony protuberance with a well-defined cortex that flares into the lesion. Which of the following radiographic features is most indicative of osteochondroma?

options.D: Joint erosion adjacent to the lesion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cortical flaring into the lesion Explanation: The characteristic radiographic feature of osteochondroma is the flaring of the host bone's cortex into the osteochondroma, indicating a benign growth. Osteochondroma: Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum. Growth via enchondral ossification, similar to normal bone development. More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence. Affects long bones, especially the femur and humerus. Clinical Presentation Usually presents as a painless mass. Symptoms may include: Formation of a bursa due to friction. Activity-related discomfort. Rare symptoms: Neuropathic pain from nerve compression. Sudden pain due to fracture. Types of Osteochondromas and Malignant Transformation Type Characteristics Risk of Malignant Transformation Solitary Osteochondroma Low risk (~1%). Difficult to determine exact incidence. ~1% Multiple Osteochondromas (MO) Higher risk (~4%). Autosomal dominant disorder with EXT1 or EXT2 gene mutations in 90% of cases. ~4% Factors affecting malignant transformation : Larger lesions with thicker cartilage caps (especially >1.5 cm). More common in trunk lesions, and rare in extremities. Suspicious changes in size or pain after skeletal maturity in MO patients. Radiographic Appearance Bony protuberance with well-defined borders. Key radiographic features : Cortex flaring into the osteochondroma. (Option B) Thin outer cortex with inner cancellous structure. Pedunculated (cauliflower-like summit) or broad sessile base. Pedunculated lesions point away from the joint toward the diaphysis. MRI findings : Cartilaginous cap thickness, generally thicker in children and thins with age. Note: Tumor appears small in radiograph and large when palpated because of the cartilage cap. Sclerotic margins with central lucency (Option A) : This is more suggestive of a bone cyst or other lesions, not osteochondroma. Irregular spiculated margins (Option C) : These are typically seen in malignant bone tumors, such as osteosarcoma. Joint erosion adjacent to the lesion (Option D) : Osteochondromas usually do not cause joint erosion, as they grow away from the joint.
